No php cannot be hosted on HubSpot. Depending on your scenario serverless functions, or just HubL may solve your issue

<@U25PYL3Q8>, thanks for your response. The problem was that I updated some css and javascript, and those were the ones not been updated. I found the answer in <https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/cos-general/i-updated-a-module-content-on-my-template-why-are-the-changes-not-displaying-on-my-content>

In the article, the author remarks that there’s a control to “lock” the module from the content manager (in the edit pages section) so you don’t override from the template section the content of the page. After locking the module, the changes updated and then you can disable again the “lock” control.
is it possible to limit the blog post that are shown in the listing  view just for mobile ( show 9 blogs posts on desktop, but only 3 on mobile)?
Yes, but it'd throw off your pagination

Ian is correct about this. I've seen quite a few people want to do this, and I always ask why. On mobile people are trained to continue to scroll down, scroll down, scroll down. Why would you want to cause a mobile user to reload a page (depending on connection, that could take more time then the person wants) when you can have 9 perfectly good blog posts for them to look through..

Besides it messing up pagination and needing you to write extra code to bring in those posts, or hide them, why... it just doesn't make sense when every other blog has 9+ blog posts on a listing page. That is what people are used to. They don't want to click to the second page for 3 more items...

in the past I would generally ask why they were looking to do this, so that I make sure I can address it or to see how it fits into the grand scheme of things. Often times a client wants to do something for a good reason, but they aren't communicating it properly. Hell, we all have that problem. A lot of the times I'm answering a question that someone else asked -- and I'm not answering what they are trying to ask.

It is good to "hear" or "listen" to a client before going into these types of things. MAke sure they feel heard, and then present what you think to be the right information as to why they shouldn't. AND IN THE CASE they do have a really good reason or some analytics or some kind of idea as to why you should do it -- maybe just say let me do a little more research and then figure out if it is really a good idea.
no one wants to just get shut down if they think they are doing something smart
